t: Isaiah 1
The*p vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
The Wickedness of Judah
Hear,*pn O heavens, and give ear, O earth; for*ld the Lord*s has spoken: “Children*ln have I reared and brought up, but*ld they have rebelled against me.
The*ln ox knows its owner, and*ld the donkey its master’s crib, but*ln Israel does not know, my*ld people do not understand.”

Ah,*pn sinful nation, a*ld people laden with iniquity, offspring*ln of evildoers, children*ld who deal corruptly! They*ln have forsaken the Lord,*s they*ld have despised the Holy One of Israel, they*ld are utterly estranged.
Why*pn will you still be struck down? Why*ld will you continue to rebel? The*ln whole head is sick, and*ld the whole heart faint.
From*ln the sole of the foot even to the head, there*ld is no soundness in it, but*ln bruises and sores and*ld raw wounds; they*ln are not pressed out or bound up or*ld softened with oil.
Your*pn country lies desolate; your*ld cities are burned with fire; in*ln your very presence foreigners*ld devour your land; it*ld is desolate, as overthrown by foreigners.
And*ln the daughter of Zion is left like*ld a booth in a vineyard, like*ln a lodge in a cucumber field, like*ld a besieged city.
If*pn the Lord*s of hosts had*ld not left us a few survivors, we*ln should have been like Sodom, and*ld become like Gomorrah.
Hear*pn the word of the Lord,*s you*ld rulers of Sodom! Give*ln ear to the teaching of our God, you*ld people of Gomorrah!

“What*ln to me is the multitude of your sacrifices? says*ld the Lord;*s I*ln have had enough of burnt offerings of rams and*ld the fat of well-fed beasts; I*ln do not delight in the blood of bulls, or*ld of lambs, or of goats.
“When*pn you come to appear before me, who*ld has required of you this*ld trampling of my courts?
Bring*ln no more vain offerings; incense*ld is an abomination to me. New*ln moon and Sabbath and the calling of convocations— I*ld cannot endure iniquity and solemn assembly.
Your*ln new moons and your appointed feasts my*ld soul hates; they*ln have become a burden to me; I*ld am weary of bearing them.
When*ln you spread out your hands, I*ld will hide my eyes from you; even*ln though you make many prayers, I*ld will not listen; your*ld hands are full of blood.
Wash*ln yourselves; make yourselves clean; remove*ld the evil of your deeds from before my eyes; cease*ln to do evil,
learn*ld to do good; seek*ln justice, correct*ld oppression; bring*ln justice to the fatherless, plead*ld the widow’s cause.
“Come*pn now, let us reason together, says the Lord:*s though*ln your sins are like scarlet, they*ld shall be as white as snow; though*ln they are red like crimson, they*ld shall become like wool.
If*ln you are willing and obedient, you*ld shall eat the good of the land;
but*ln if you refuse and rebel, you*ld shall be eaten by the sword; for*ld the mouth of the Lord*s has spoken.”
The Unfaithful City
How*pn the faithful city has*ld become a whore, she*ld who was full of justice! Righteousness*ln lodged in her, but*ld now murderers.
Your*ln silver has become dross, your*ld best wine mixed with water.

Your*ln princes are rebels and*ld companions of thieves. Everyone*ln loves a bribe and*ld runs after gifts. They*ln do not bring justice to the fatherless, and*ld the widow’s cause does not come to them.
Therefore*pn the Lord declares, the*ld Lord*s of hosts, the*ld Mighty One of Israel: “Ah,*ln I will get relief from my enemies and*ld avenge myself on my foes.
I*ln will turn my hand against you and*ld will smelt away your dross as with lye and*ld remove all your alloy.
And*ln I will restore your judges as at the first, and*ld your counselors as at the beginning. Afterward*ln you shall be called the city of righteousness, the*ld faithful city.”
Zion*pn shall be redeemed by justice, and*ld those in her who repent, by righteousness.
But*ln rebels and sinners shall be broken together, and*ld those who forsake the Lord*s shall be consumed.
For*ln they shall be ashamed of the oaks that*ld you desired; and*ln you shall blush for the gardens that*ld you have chosen.
For*ln you shall be like an oak whose*ld leaf withers, and*ld like a garden without water.
And*ln the strong shall become tinder, and*ld his work a spark, and*ln both of them shall burn together, with*ld none to quench them.
Isaiah 2
The Mountain of the Lord
The*p word that Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

It*pn shall come to pass in the latter days that*ld the mountain of the house of the Lord*s shall*ln be established as the highest of the mountains, and*ld shall be lifted up above the hills; and*ln all the nations shall flow to it,

and*ld many peoples shall come, and say: “Come,*ln let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,*s to*ld the house of the God of Jacob, that*ln he may teach us his ways and*ld that we may walk in his paths.” For*ln out of Zion shall go forth the law, and*ld the word of the Lord*s from Jerusalem.

He*ln shall judge between the nations, and*ld shall decide disputes for many peoples; and*ln they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and*ld their spears into pruning hooks; nation*ln shall not lift up sword against nation, neither*ld shall they learn war anymore.
O*pn house of Jacob, come,*ld let us walk in*ld the light of the Lord.*s
The Day of the Lord

For*pn you have rejected your people, the*ld house of Jacob, because*ln they are full of things from the east and*ld of fortune-tellers like the Philistines, and*ld they strike hands with the children of foreigners.
Their*ln land is filled with silver and gold, and*ld there is no end to their treasures; their*ln land is filled with horses, and*ld there is no end to their chariots.
Their*ln land is filled with idols; they*ld bow down to the work of their hands, to*ld what their own fingers have made.
So*ln man is humbled, and*ld each one is brought low— do*ld not forgive them!
Enter*ln into the rock and*ld hide in the dust from*ln before the terror of the Lord,*s and*ld from the splendor of his majesty.
The*ln haughty looks of man shall be brought low, and*ld the lofty pride of men shall be humbled, and*ln the Lord*s alone will be exalted in that day.
For*pn the Lord*s of hosts has a day against*ld all that is proud and lofty, against*ld all that is lifted up— and it shall be brought low;
against*ln all the cedars of Lebanon, lofty*ld and lifted up; and*ld against all the oaks of Bashan;
against*ln all the lofty mountains, and*ld against all the uplifted hills;
against*ln every high tower, and*ld against every fortified wall;
against*ln all the ships of Tarshish, and*ld against all the beautiful craft.
And*ln the haughtiness of man shall be humbled, and*ld the lofty pride of men shall be brought low, and*ld the Lord*s alone will be exalted in that day.
And*ln the idols shall utterly pass away.

And*ln people shall enter the caves of the rocks and*ld the holes of the ground, from*ln before the terror of the Lord,*s and*ld from the splendor of his majesty, when*ld he rises to terrify the earth.
In*pn that day mankind will cast away their*ld idols of silver and their idols of gold, which*ln they made for themselves to worship, to*ld the moles and to the bats,
to*ln enter the caverns of the rocks and*ld the clefts of the cliffs, from*ln before the terror of the Lord,*s and*ld from the splendor of his majesty, when*ld he rises to terrify the earth.
Stop*ln regarding man in*ld whose nostrils is breath, for*ld of what account is he?
Isaiah 3
Judgment on Judah and Jerusalem
For*pn behold, the Lord God*s of hosts is*ld taking away from Jerusalem and from Judah support*ln and supply, all*ld support of bread, and*ld all support of water;
the*ln mighty man and the soldier, the*ld judge and the prophet, the*ld diviner and the elder,
the*ln captain of fifty and*ld the man of rank, the*ln counselor and the skillful magician and*ld the expert in charms.
And*ln I will make boys their princes, and*ld infants shall rule over them.
And*ln the people will oppress one another, every*ld one his fellow and*ld every one his neighbor; the*ln youth will be insolent to the elder, and*ld the despised to the honorable.
For*pn a man will take hold of his brother in*ld the house of his father, saying: “You*ln have a cloak; you*ld shall be our leader, and*ln this heap of ruins shall*ld be under your rule”;
in*ln that day he will speak out, saying: “I*ln will not be a healer; in*ld my house there is neither bread nor cloak; you*ln shall not make me leader*ld of the people.”
For*ln Jerusalem has stumbled, and*ld Judah has fallen, because*ln their speech and their deeds are against the Lord,*s defying*ld his glorious presence.
For*pn the look on their faces bears witness against them; they*ld proclaim their sin like Sodom; they*ld do not hide it. Woe*ln to them! For*ld they have brought evil on themselves.
Tell*ln the righteous that it shall be well with them, for*ld they shall eat the fruit of their deeds.
Woe*ln to the wicked! It shall be ill with him, for*ld what his hands have dealt out shall be done to him.
My*ln people— infants are their oppressors, and*ld women rule over them. O*ln my people, your guides mislead you and*ld they have swallowed up the course of your paths.
The*pn Lord*s has taken his place to contend; he*ld stands to judge peoples.
The*ln Lord*s will enter into judgment with*ld the elders and princes of his people: “It*ln is you who have devoured the vineyard, the*ld spoil of the poor is in your houses.
What*ln do you mean by crushing my people, by*ld grinding the face of the poor?” declares*l the Lord God*s of hosts.
The*pn Lord*s said: Because*ln the daughters of Zion are haughty and*ld walk with outstretched necks, glancing*ld wantonly with their eyes, mincing*ln along as they go, tinkling*ld with their feet,
therefore*ln the Lord will strike with a scab the*ld heads of the daughters of Zion, and*ld the Lord*s will lay bare their secret parts.
In*p that day the Lord will take away the finery of the anklets, the headbands, and the crescents;
the pendants, the bracelets, and the scarves;
the headdresses, the armlets, the sashes, the perfume boxes, and the amulets;
the signet rings and nose rings;
the festal robes, the mantles, the cloaks, and the handbags;
the mirrors, the linen garments, the turbans, and the veils.

Instead*pn of perfume there will be rottenness; and*ld instead of a belt, a rope; and*ln instead of well-set hair, baldness; and*ld instead of a rich robe, a skirt of sackcloth; and*ld branding instead of beauty.
Your*ln men shall fall by the sword and*ld your mighty men in battle.
And*ln her gates shall lament and mourn; empty,*ld she shall sit on the ground.
Isaiah 4
And*p seven women shall take hold of one man in that day, saying, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own clothes, only let us be called by your name; take away our reproach.”
The Branch of the Lord Glorified
In*p that day the branch of the Lord*s shall be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land shall be the pride and honor of the survivors of Israel.
And he who is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy, everyone who has been recorded for life in Jerusalem,
when the Lord shall have washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and cleansed the bloodstains of Jerusalem from its midst by a spirit of judgment and by a spirit of burning.

Then the Lord*s will create over the whole site of Mount Zion and over her assemblies a cloud by day, and smoke and the shining of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory there will be a canopy.
There will be a booth for shade by day from the heat, and for a refuge and a shelter from the storm and rain.
Isaiah 5
The Vineyard of the Lord Destroyed
Let*pn me sing for my beloved my*ld love song concerning his vineyard: My*ln beloved had a vineyard on*ld a very fertile hill.

He*ln dug it and cleared it of stones, and*ld planted it with choice vines; he*ln built a watchtower in the midst of it, and*ld hewed out a wine vat in it; and*ln he looked for it to yield grapes, but*ld it yielded wild grapes.
And*pn now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and*ld men of Judah, judge*ln between me and my vineyard.
What*ln more was there to do for my vineyard, that*ld I have not done in it? When*ln I looked for it to yield grapes, why*ld did it yield wild grapes?
And*pn now I will tell you what*ld I will do to my vineyard. I*ln will remove its hedge, and*ld it shall be devoured; I*ln will break down its wall, and*ld it shall be trampled down.
I*ln will make it a waste; it*ld shall not be pruned or hoed, and*ld briers and thorns shall grow up; I*ln will also command the clouds that*ld they rain no rain upon it.

For*pn the vineyard of the Lord*s of hosts is*ld the house of Israel, and*ln the men of Judah are*ld his pleasant planting; and*ln he looked for justice, but*ld behold, bloodshed; for*ln righteousness, but*ld behold, an outcry!
Woe to the Wicked
Woe*pn to those who join house to house, who*ld add field to field, until*ln there is no more room, and*ld you are made to dwell alone in*ld the midst of the land.
The*ln Lord*s of hosts has sworn in my hearing: “Surely*ln many houses shall be desolate, large*ld and beautiful houses, without inhabitant.
For*ln ten acres of vineyard shall yield but one bath, and*ld a homer of seed shall yield but an ephah.”
Woe*pn to those who rise early in the morning, that*ld they may run after strong drink, who*ln tarry late into the evening as*ld wine inflames them!
They*ln have lyre and harp, tambourine*ld and flute and wine at their feasts, but*ln they do not regard the deeds of the Lord,*s or*ld see the work of his hands.
Therefore*pn my people go into exile for*ld lack of knowledge; their*ln honored men go hungry, and*ld their multitude is parched with thirst.
Therefore*ln Sheol has enlarged its appetite and*ld opened its mouth beyond measure, and*ln the nobility of Jerusalem and her multitude will go down, her*ld revelers and he who exults in her.
Man*ln is humbled, and each one is brought low, and*ld the eyes of the haughty are brought low.
But*ln the Lord*s of hosts is exalted in justice, and*ld the Holy God shows himself holy in righteousness.
Then*ln shall the lambs graze as in their pasture, and*ld nomads shall eat among the ruins of the rich.
Woe*pn to those who draw iniquity with cords of falsehood, who*ld draw sin as with cart ropes,
who*ln say: “Let him be quick, let*ld him speed his work that*ld we may see it; let*ln the counsel of the Holy One of Israel draw near, and*ld let it come, that we may know it!”
Woe*ln to those who call evil good and*ld good evil, who*ln put darkness for light and*ld light for darkness, who*ln put bitter for sweet and*ld sweet for bitter!
Woe*ln to those who are wise in their own eyes, and*ld shrewd in their own sight!
Woe*ln to those who are heroes at drinking wine, and*ld valiant men in mixing strong drink,
who*ln acquit the guilty for a bribe, and*ld deprive the innocent of his right!

Therefore,*pn as the tongue of fire devours the stubble, and*ld as dry grass sinks down in the flame, so*ln their root will be as rottenness, and*ld their blossom go up like dust; for*ln they have rejected the law of the Lord*s of hosts, and*ld have despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

Therefore*ln the anger of the Lord*s was kindled against his people, and*ld he stretched out his hand against them and struck them, and*ld the mountains quaked; and*ln their corpses were as refuse in*ld the midst of the streets. For*ln all this his anger has not turned away, and*ld his hand is stretched out still.
He*pn will raise a signal for nations far away, and*ld whistle for them from the ends of the earth; and*ln behold, quickly, speedily they come!
None*ln is weary, none stumbles, none*ld slumbers or sleeps, not*ln a waistband is loose, not*ld a sandal strap broken;
their*ln arrows are sharp, all*ld their bows bent, their*ln horses’ hoofs seem like flint, and*ld their wheels like the whirlwind.
Their*ln roaring is like a lion, like*ld young lions they roar; they*ln growl and seize their prey; they*ld carry it off, and none can rescue.
They*ln will growl over it on that day, like*ld the growling of the sea. And*ln if one looks to the land, behold,*ld darkness and distress; and*ln the light is darkened by its clouds.
Isaiah 6
Isaiah’s Vision of the Lord
In*p the year that King Uzziah died I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up; and the train of his robe filled the temple.
Above him stood the seraphim. Each had six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
And one called to another and said: “Holy,*pn holy, holy is the Lord*s of hosts; the*ln whole earth is full of his glory!”
And*p the foundations of the thresholds shook at the voice of him who called, and the house was filled with smoke.
And I said: “Woe is me! For I am lost; for I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the Lord*s of hosts!”
Then*p one of the seraphim flew to me, having in his hand a burning coal that he had taken with tongs from the altar.
And he touched my mouth and said: “Behold, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away, and your sin atoned for.”
Isaiah’s Commission from the Lord
And*p I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?” Then I said, “Here I am! Send me.”
And he said, “Go, and say to this people: “‘Keep*pn on hearing, but do not understand; keep*ln on seeing, but do not perceive.’

Make*ln the heart of this people dull, and*ld their ears heavy, and*ld blind their eyes; lest*ln they see with their eyes, and*ld hear with their ears, and*ln understand with their hearts, and*ld turn and be healed.”
Then*ln I said, “How long, O Lord?” And*ln he said: “Until*ln cities lie waste without*ld inhabitant, and*ln houses without people, and*ld the land is a desolate waste,
and*ln the Lord*s removes people far away, and*ld the forsaken places are many in the midst of the land.
And*ln though a tenth remain in it, it*ld will be burned again, like*ln a terebinth or an oak, whose*ld stump remains when*ld it is felled.” The*ln holy seed is its stump.
Isaiah 7
Isaiah Sent to King Ahaz

In*p the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, son of Uzziah, king of Judah, Rezin the king of Syria and Pekah the son of Remaliah the king of Israel came up to Jerusalem to wage war against it, but could not yet mount an attack against it.
When the house of David was told, “Syria is in league with Ephraim,” the heart of Ahaz and the heart of his people shook as the trees of the forest shake before the wind.
And*p the Lord*s said to Isaiah, “Go out to meet Ahaz, you and Shear-jashub your son, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the Washer’s Field.

And say to him, ‘Be careful, be quiet, do not fear, and do not let your heart be faint because of these two smoldering stumps of firebrands, at the fierce anger of Rezin and Syria and the son of Remaliah.
Because Syria, with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah, has devised evil against you, saying,
“Let us go up against Judah and terrify it, and let us conquer it for ourselves, and set up the son of Tabeel as king in the midst of it,”
thus says the Lord God:*s “‘It*pn shall not stand, and*ld it shall not come to pass.
For*ln the head of Syria is Damascus, and*ld the head of Damascus is Rezin. And*ln within sixty-five years Ephraim*ld will be shattered from being a people.
And*ln the head of Ephraim is Samaria, and*ld the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah. If*ln you are not firm in faith, you*ld will not be firm at all.’”
The Sign of Immanuel
Again*p the Lord*s spoke to Ahaz:
“Ask a sign of the Lord*s your God; let it be deep as Sheol or high as heaven.”
But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, and I will not put the Lord*s to the test.”
And he said, “Hear then, O house of David! Is it too little for you to weary men, that you weary my God also?
Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign. Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.
He shall eat curds and honey when he knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good.
For before the boy knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land whose two kings you dread will be deserted.
The Lord*s will bring upon you and upon your people and upon your father’s house such days as have not come since the day that Ephraim departed from Judah— the king of Assyria!”
In*p that day the Lord*s will whistle for the fly that is at the end of the streams of Egypt, and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
And they will all come and settle in the steep ravines, and in the clefts of the rocks, and on all the thornbushes, and on all the pastures.
In*p that day the Lord will shave with a razor that is hired beyond the River— with the king of Assyria— the head and the hair of the feet, and it will sweep away the beard also.
In*p that day a man will keep alive a young cow and two sheep,
and because of the abundance of milk that they give, he will eat curds, for everyone who is left in the land will eat curds and honey.
In*p that day every place where there used to be a thousand vines, worth a thousand shekels of silver, will become briers and thorns.
With bow and arrows a man will come there, for all the land will be briers and thorns.
And as for all the hills that used to be hoed with a hoe, you will not come there for fear of briers and thorns, but they will become a place where cattle are let loose and where sheep tread.
Isaiah 8
The Coming Assyrian Invasion
Then*p the Lord*s said to me, “Take a large tablet and write on it in common characters, ‘Belonging to Maher-shalal-hash-baz.’
And I will get reliable witnesses, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah, to attest for me.”
And*p I went to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the Lord*s said to me, “Call his name Maher-shalal-hash-baz;
for before the boy knows how to cry ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be carried away before the king of Assyria.”
The*p Lord*s spoke to me again:
“Because this people has refused the waters of Shiloah that flow gently, and rejoice over Rezin and the son of Remaliah,

therefore, behold, the Lord is bringing up against them the waters of the River, mighty and many, the king of Assyria and all his glory. And it will rise over all its channels and go over all its banks,
and it will sweep on into Judah, it will overflow and pass on, reaching even to the neck, and its outspread wings will fill the breadth of your land, O Immanuel.”
Be*pn broken, you peoples, and be shattered; give*ld ear, all you far countries; strap*ln on your armor and be shattered; strap*ld on your armor and be shattered.
Take*ln counsel together, but it will come to nothing; speak*ld a word, but it will not stand, for*ld God is with us.
Fear God, Wait for the Lord
For*p the Lord*s spoke thus to me with his strong hand upon me, and warned me not to walk in the way of this people, saying:
“Do not call conspiracy all that this people calls conspiracy, and do not fear what they fear, nor be in dread.
But the Lord*s of hosts, him you shall honor as holy. Let him be your fear, and let him be your dread.
And he will become a sanctuary and a stone of offense and a rock of stumbling to both houses of Israel, a trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
And many shall stumble on it. They shall fall and be broken; they shall be snared and taken.”
Bind*p up the testimony; seal the teaching among my disciples.
I will wait for the Lord,*s who is hiding his face from the house of Jacob, and I will hope in him.
Behold, I and the children whom the Lord*s has given me are signs and portents in Israel from the Lord*s of hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.
And when they say to you, “Inquire of the mediums and the necromancers who chirp and mutter,” should not a people inquire of their God? Should they inquire of the dead on behalf of the living?
To the teaching and to the testimony! If they will not speak according to this word, it is because they have no dawn.

They will pass through the land, greatly distressed and hungry. And when they are hungry, they will be enraged and will speak contemptuously against their king and their God, and turn their faces upward.
And they will look to the earth, but behold, distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish. And they will be thrust into thick darkness.
Isaiah 9
For to Us a Child Is Born

But*p there will be no gloom for her who was in anguish. In the former time he brought into contempt the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, but in the latter time he has made glorious the way of the sea, the land beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations.
The*pn people who walked in darkness have*ld seen a great light; those*ln who dwelt in a land of deep darkness, on*ld them has light shone.
You*ln have multiplied the nation; you*ld have increased its joy; they*ln rejoice before you as*ld with joy at the harvest, as*ld they are glad when they divide the spoil.
For*ln the yoke of his burden, and*ld the staff for his shoulder, the*ld rod of his oppressor, you*ld have broken as on the day of Midian.
For*ln every boot of the tramping warrior in battle tumult and*ld every garment rolled in blood will*ld be burned as fuel for the fire.

For*ln to us a child is born, to*ld us a son is given; and*ln the government shall be upon his shoulder, and*ld his name shall be called Wonderful*ln Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting*ld Father, Prince of Peace.

Of*ln the increase of his government and of peace there*ld will be no end, on*ln the throne of David and over his kingdom, to*ld establish it and to uphold it with*ln justice and with righteousness from*ld this time forth and forevermore. The*ln zeal of the Lord*s of hosts will do this.
Judgment on Arrogance and Oppression
The*pn Lord has sent a word against Jacob, and*ld it will fall on Israel;
and*ln all the people will know, Ephraim*ld and the inhabitants of Samaria, who*ld say in pride and in arrogance of heart:
“The*ln bricks have fallen, but*ld we will build with dressed stones; the*ln sycamores have been cut down, but*ld we will put cedars in their place.”
But*ln the Lord*s raises the adversaries of Rezin against him, and*ld stirs up his enemies.
The*ln Syrians on the east and the Philistines on the west devour*ld Israel with open mouth. For*ln all this his anger has not turned away, and*ld his hand is stretched out still.
The*pn people did not turn to him who struck them, nor*ld inquire of the Lord*s of hosts.
So*ln the Lord*s cut off from Israel head and tail, palm*ld branch and reed in one day—
the*ln elder and honored man is the head, and*ld the prophet who teaches lies is the tail;
for*ln those who guide this people have been leading them astray, and*ld those who are guided by them are swallowed up.

Therefore*ln the Lord does not rejoice over their young men, and*ld has no compassion on their fatherless and widows; for*ln everyone is godless and an evildoer, and*ld every mouth speaks folly. For*ln all this his anger has not turned away, and*ld his hand is stretched out still.
For*pn wickedness burns like a fire; it*ld consumes briers and thorns; it*ln kindles the thickets of the forest, and*ld they roll upward in a column of smoke.
Through*ln the wrath of the Lord*s of hosts the*ld land is scorched, and*ln the people are like fuel for the fire; no*ld one spares another.
They*ln slice meat on the right, but are still hungry, and*ld they devour on the left, but are not satisfied; each*ln devours the flesh of his own arm,
Manasseh*ln devours Ephraim, and Ephraim devours Manasseh; together*ld they are against Judah. For*ln all this his anger has not turned away, and*ld his hand is stretched out still.
Isaiah 10
Woe*pn to those who decree iniquitous decrees, and*ld the writers who keep writing oppression,
to*ln turn aside the needy from justice and*ld to rob the poor of my people of their right, that*ln widows may be their spoil, and*ld that they may make the fatherless their prey!
What*ln will you do on the day of punishment, in*ld the ruin that will come from afar? To*ln whom will you flee for help, and*ld where will you leave your wealth?
Nothing*ln remains but to crouch among the prisoners or*ld fall among the slain. For*ln all this his anger has not turned away, and*ld his hand is stretched out still.
Judgment on Arrogant Assyria
